comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I spy with my little eye something beginning with IPSWICH ! Which indeed implies the 'Joseph Conrad', which came from Ipswich (UK). See - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Conrad_(ship) .

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The crew seem to be singing along to the piano accordion - a sea shanty perhaps? Amazingly there are a couple of 1930s videos of this vessel at sea on YouTube - youtu.be/gQmWeePa2OY youtu.be/vVcZLBjsurY

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The 'Joseph Conrad' was in Sydney (moored in Double Bay) from 9/12/1935 to 18/12/1935 according to these two SMH articles with illustrations - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17208142 - including the reference to Andrew Lindsay (see note) trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17231756

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Wow, thank you for all that information beachcomber. We have uploaded a set of photos of JOSEPH CONRAD and the crew including an image that was in one of the articles you posted!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] That's a terrific set of photos - it's like a jigsaw coming together. Author/owner/skipper/photographer Alan Villiers (1903-82) (see note top left) was an interesting character, undoubtedly well known to the ANMM - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Villiers and www.rmg.co.uk/explore/sea-and-ships/facts/ships-and-seafa...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Indeed, and there are more to come! Thanks for those links as well.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
